KIM HAMAD-SCHIFFERLI:
What we would like to do

is to come up with some
way to control biomolecules
in an electronic manner.

This could be applied
to control genes

that are related
in cancer, and it

could use as a
diagnosis for that
or any genetic-related disease.

And there's a
considerable amount

of interest in gene therapy
or controlling diseases
at the genetic level.

And this would be a handle
by which you could do that.

And so normally, when you
think of electronic control,
you think of electrodes.

And that's very convenient for
things that are quite large.

But when you start to
go to biomolecules,

it's hard to directly
interface to them.

And so what we've
done is to come up

with a new way to
control biomolecules.

And that is by using an
antenna directly attached
to the biomolecule.

And so what we
would like to do is

to use this antenna to
control biological molecules
in their real environments.

But what we're starting
with is to use this antenna

to control biomolecules
simply in solution.

So [? what Kate ?] is
doing is synthesizing

gold nanoparticles,
which will be
our antennas for biomolecules.

And this occurs by a
simple chemical reaction

in which a compound
containing a gold atom
is converted into gold clusters.

Once the gold nanoparticles
have been made,

[? Kate ?] reacts to
them with the biomolecule
that we're going to control.

And once that
reaction occurs, we

need to purify the desired
product out of that.

And so this is
done by a technique
called gel electrophoresis.

So what you're seeing
now is [? Kate ?]

pipetting the
solution that's going
to be purified into a gel.

And this is placed in a gel
electrophoresis apparatus.

And an electric field
is run across the gel

and then separates
out all the products.

And finally, once
the molecule has

been extracted from
the gel, somehow

controls the biomolecule
by placing it

in the apparatus, which sends
the energy to the antenna.
And this is the coil.

And then we incorporate this
with an apparatus, which

can probe whether or not
the bottom molecule has
been controlled.

And we can see this
on a computer screen

as a change in the
optical absorption.

In many ways that
people have come up

with to control biomolecules,
but one advantage

of this technique is that
it can go through tissue.

So there's been some work
where people have used lasers.

And the problem with
lasers is that they

can't penetrate tissue unless
you use certain wavelengths.

And typically, these wavelengths
are not very convenient.

And in our case, we send energy
using radiofrequency fields.

And this radiofrequency field
can actually go through tissue.

So this can be done
inside an animal.

What we're doing now is simply
a proof of principle experiment.

You can even do this
at very simple levels.

But we're working hard on trying
to get this inside of a cell.

And then after that, the
next step is to an organism.

And so perhaps on the
order of 10 years,

we might be able to do
this inside of an organism.

What I'm really
interested in and studying

is bringing the
perspective of somebody

from the physical
sciences to biology.

And more and more people
are doing this now.

And what's clear is that people
from the physical sciences

and engineering can start to
ask different questions than has

been asked of biology or
bring new perspectives.

And I think that's very exciting
because a lot of new ideas
flow.

And then as with any
interdisciplinary area,
there's a lot of changes.
